title: Former RBS boss Fred Goodwin told to cut back hedges after four-year battle with neighbours
text:
-9.971 
Fred Goodwin's 20ft hedges at his £3.5m Scottish home had angered neighbours 
Former RBS chief executive Fred Goodwin (Stuttgart: GDW.SG - news ) has been told to cut down an 20ft hedge at his Scottish mansion that has "overpowered" his neighbours' gardens. 
The ex-banker kept the giant leylandii hedge after buying the £3.5m property in 2010, as it blocked views of the back of his home. 
The move angered his neighbours, who claimed the vegetation prevents light from reaching their gardens and spoils their enjoyment of their properties. 
On Friday, after a four-year row, Edinburgh City Council sided with the homeowners, who took action under the High Hedges (Scotland) Act (Frankfurt: 0LW.F - news ) 2013 and ordered Mr Goodwin to cut it back. 
"I can appreciate why the appellants consider that the western hedge is too high," Scottish Government planning reporter David Liddell ruled. 
"Their rear gardens are relatively shallow, made smaller still by conservatories or more substantial extensions. 
"This makes them particularly sensitive to any tall boundary fences or hedges. 
"In my view the hedge, noting the narrow depths of the rear gardens, presently has a dominant and somewhat oppressive effect when experienced from these gardens. 
"Overall, however, I consider that the hedge, at its current height, adversely effects the enjoyment of numbers 5-13 which the occupants of those properties could reasonably expect to have." 
Mr Goodwin will have to cut back the hedges to a maximum of 14ft, the Daily Mail reported . 
In a joint statement to the Scottish Government, the neighbours said: "We would wish to stress that the appearance of this hedge is both dominant and oppressive. 
"These two rows are not only high and block light, but their combined growth, thickness of trunks, compact branches provide a real density such that, in most areas allow no light at all to pass through. 
"There are real feelings of dominance and oppression which have gradually built up over the years - due to lack of proper tree management. 
"The gardens may not be large but they have always been the same size, the issue is that as the trees and hedge have become enlarged they have overpowered the gardens." 
Mr Goodwin was at the helm of RBS (LSE: RBS.L - news ) when it ran into financial trouble in 2008, with the Government eventually having to step in with a £45bn bailout to ensure its survival. He was subsequently stripped of his knighthood but retained an annual pension of £342,500. 
He later told a committee of MPs he "could not be more sorry" for what had happened.
